score_OPTION_1.____description: add the individual "scores" of the four categories (F-A-I-R) of all ro components (e.g. ro-crate, software1, ontology1, other) and calculate the percentage (e.g. 34/52 -> 65%).

total_sum.___description: sum of all component fairnesses score togethe. total_sum = findable_score + acessible_score...

score_OPTION_1.PROS: gives more weight to the most important categories (those with the most tests done)
score_OPTION_1.CONS: not all categories are weighted equally

score_OPTION_2.____description: add the individual "total_passed_tests/total_tests_run" of the four categories (F-A-I-R) of all ro components (e.g. ro-crate, software1, ontology1, other) and calculate the percentage (e.g. 34/52 -> 65%).

total_sum.___description: sum of all component "total_passed_tests/total_tests_run" togethe. total_sum = findable_test_pass + acessible_test_pass... / findable_test_run + acessible_test_run

score_OPTION_2.PROS: gives more weight to the most important categories (those with the most tests done)
CONS: there may be unimportant tests that should not be counted for the score. We would not take the score given by f-uji. It would have to be recalculated according to the tests done and passed.
not all categories are weighted equally

score_OPTION_3.____description: arithmetic mean of the "score" of each category

findable.______: sum of all component fairnesses score together (ro.findable + ontology.findable + software.findable + dataset.findable + other.findable)

score_OPTION_3.PROS: all categories are weighted the same
score_OPTION_3.CONS: having few tests in one category has the same weight as having many tests in another category. Few tests are heavily weighted. Many tests weight little.

score_OPTION_4.____description: arithmetic mean of the "total_passed_tests/total_tests_run"  of each category

findable.______: sum of all component fairnesses tests together (ro.findable.total_passed_tests + ro.findable.total_tests_run + sowftware.findable.total_passed_tests...)

score_OPTION_4.PROS: all categories are weighted the same
CONS: there may be unimportant tests that should not be counted for the score. We would not take the score given by f-uji. It would have to be recalculated according to the tests done and passed.
having few tests in one category has the same weight as having many tests in another category. Few tests are heavily weighted. Many tests weight little.

checks.title: (Meta)data are assigned a globally unique and persistent identifier
checks.explanation: Identifier is resolvable and follows a defined unique identifier syntax (IRI, URL)
checks.description: This checks if the given identifier match the IRI or URL syntax.

checks.title: Data are described with rich metadata
checks.explanation: All the minimum metadata were found
checks.description: This check verifies if the The following  minimum metadata [context, graph, autor, license other node inside graph distict from autor] are present

checks.title: Content negotiation for RDF and HTML
checks.description: This check verifies of the ontology URI is published following the right content negotiation for RDF and HTML

checks.title: Open protocol
checks.explanation: The ontology uses an open protocol
checks.description: This check verifies if the ontology uses an open protocol (HTTP or HTTPS)

checks.title: Metadata are accessible, even when ontology is not
checks.explanation: Ontology not found in a public registry
checks.description: Metadata are accessible even when the ontology is no longer available. Since the metadata is usually included in the ontology, this check verifies whether the ontology is registered in a public metadata registry (LOV)

checks.title: Software is assigned a globally unique and persistent identifier
checks.explanation: A Digital Object Identifier (DOI) is assigned to the Software
checks.description: This checks if there ir at least one DOI for this Software

checks.title: Different versions of the same software must be assigned distinct identifiers
checks.explanation: Each version must have a different identifier
checks.description: This checks if every version has different and uniques identifiers

checks.title: Metadata is represented using a formal knowledge representation language.
description: Parsable, structured metadata (JSON-LD, RDFa) is embedded in the landing page XHTML/HTML code
Parsable, graph data (RDF, JSON-LD) is accessible through content negotiation, typed links or sparql endpoint

checks.title: Metadata uses semantic resources
description: Vocabulary namespace URIs can be identified in metadata
Namespaces of known semantic resources can be identified in metadata

checks.title: Data is assigned a globally unique identifier.
description: Identifier is resolvable and follows a defined unique identifier syntax (IRI, URL)
Identifier is not resolvable but follows an UUID or HASH type syntax

checks.title: Data is assigned a persistent identifier.
description: Identifier follows a defined persistent identifier syntax

checks.title: Metadata includes descriptive core elements (creator, title, data identifier, publisher, publication date, summary and keywords) to support data findability.
description: Metadata has been made available via common web methods
Metadata is embedded in the landing page XHTML/HTML code
Metadata is accessible through content negotiation
Metadata is accessible via typed links
Metadata is accessible via signposting links
Core data citation metadata is available

checks.title: Metadata includes the identifier of the data it describes.
description: Metadata contains data content related information (file name, size, type)
Metadata contains a PID or URL which indicates the location of the downloadable data content

checks.title: Metadata is offered in such a way that it can be retrieved programmatically.
description: Metadata is given in a way major search engines can ingest it for their catalogues (JSON-LD, Dublin Core, RDFa)
Metadata is registered in major research data registries (DataCite)
